posts.cooked:
Hello
It has been a few months now and it is annoying at times when you have to chat a lot especially about technical stuff - spelling is important.

I already tried uninstall/reinstall etc. a few times in various months.

FLATPAK Signal version installed.

Thanks
M
Meaning… that was probably since July or so on Linux Mint 22.1 Xia and now on 22.2 = same - nothing changed.

Just updated to 7.80.0 ⁨production⁩ on Linux Mint 22.2 - no change
Quite a bother now… everywhere else works fine, but I use 90% this Linux PC!
Yes, I added en-gb from hunspell = NO change

signalled:

Is Signal forum dead ?

It isn’t, but if there are no answers, usually it means that noone else here is experiencing this issue or no one has your setup. It’s also possible that other people here on your OS don’t use spellcheck, so they aren’t affected.

Generally, it would help if others could reproduce this, because it would get them interested in trying to debug this.

Have you enabled what is mentioned here:

https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360049188372-Language-Options#desktop

yes, it is enabled

I already did all the obvious, install uninstall etc.
I guess it stays like this… strange

PS I do have a standard installation with no system problems - when I do check for update - all is fine - no errors etc.

I might try it in a VM to see how it looks on my end, are you on mint with Cinnamon or another Desktop?

signalled:

FLATPAK Signal version installed

Also worth mentioning that the Flatpak version isn’t technically official. Have you tried installing through apt?

Signal Messenger

Download Signal

Download Signal for Android, iOS, Linux, macOS, and Windows.

I tend to use flatpak, as I do like to keep separate compartments and also - if I am not wrong (linux newbie here) it can sometime be hard to remove Debian.
I normally do that when a Flatpak does not work well, never thought about Signal !
Will try - thanks for the reminder!!

I think I did have a problem and after installing Flatpak worked, so it may do the same now… and probably lose chat threads too.

Uninstalled Flatpak and installed Debian - no change
It is beyond me.

I am no expert but, might it be file permission? Although Signal should warn of non-accessible file (spellcheck).

I also deleted the config file as ‘read’ somewhere and re-linked - no change - but that may just be related to messages and not settings…

signalled:

it can sometime be hard to remove Debian

I don’t know what you mean by this. Debian is a linux operating system, just like your operating system linux mint. Linux mint is based on debian, as are many other linux distros.

You can use different ways to install programs on linux systems. One of the programs to do this is flatpak. It gives you the ability to access their servers, get installable files and install them on your device. But the files they have on their servers are not officially provided by Signal.

Another program for installing is apt. It checks a list of sources you have on your device for program code you would like to install and then also gets the files and installs them. This is officially supported by Signal and they have instructions on the page I provided above:

# NOTE: These instructions only work for 64-bit Debian-based Linux distributions such as Ubuntu, Mint etc.

# 1. Install our official public software signing key:

wget -O- https://updates.signal.org/desktop/apt/keys.asc | gpg --dearmor > signal-desktop-keyring.gpg;

cat signal-desktop-keyring.gpg | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/signal-desktop-keyring.gpg > /dev/null

# 2. Add our repository to your list of repositories:

wget -O signal-desktop.sources https://updates.signal.org/static/desktop/apt/signal-desktop.sources;

cat signal-desktop.sources | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/signal-desktop.sources > /dev/null

# 3. Update your package database and install Signal:

sudo apt update && sudo apt install signal-desktop

In step one, you get the key to verify that the code you are getting in the future is authentic.

In step two you add the place where Signal publishes the code to your list of program code sources.

In step three you search through all your sources (update), checking what is available there, and then you install signal-desktop. This last step is equivalent to “flatpak install flathub org.signal.Signal”.

Since flathub uses their own infrastructure as a source, you don’t need steps one and two for the flatpak installation.

signalled:

Uninstalled Flatpak and installed Debian

This also doesn’t make sense. You may have removed the Signal installation you got through flatpak, but “installing debian” has nothing to do with Signal, that would mean removing your operating system (linux mint) and replacing it with debian. I don’t believe that is what you mean.

Can you:

FIRST: open a terminal uninstall the version from flatpak (flatpak uninstall org.signal.Signal) and if you have tried something with apt already also remove that (sudo apt remove signal-desktop)

SECOND: copy paste the exact instructions cited above

desert_nip:

Debian-based

Done all that…

I am no Linux expert but it is a - lets call it habit - one states ‘Debian Install’ meaning a Debian-based install (not Flatpak or snap or whichever),
Your Signal install instructions from Signal page, are a direct install on Debian, while Flatpak is… a flat pak - i.e. a self contained installation.

That was all.

PS installing as Flatpak protect Debian system from possible problems, Flatpak being a self-containing install.

No change on last update today and I also noticed on last update, the chat went to green, instea of the default blue I had!
That too does not work!

As mentioned, I re-installed it twice, my wild guess… is the setting script in need of a fix? Without re-installing it all again? Meaning could it get corrupted?

mmm

Further info.

Just uninstalled Flatpak version, then used Synaptic and installed Beta - just to test.

It seems it does not like my computer.

Still no spellcheck

Note:
Linux Mint 22.2 all updated and all functional, not had a single glitch in months.
Unfortunately, I could not reproduce this issue in my VM. Is it happenining on any language you choose?

Hi
Yes, any language.

I also uninstalled again and re-installed using these instruction, as it seems they are a matching for Mint 22.2 and nothing changed.

I guess I cannot do much.
Thanks

For your information only…

By the way - I do know it is off topic - but latest update the text field not active re-appeared.

I just replied or forwarded a few messages and I had to click onto text field to activate it.
